Data Structures

struct  AlarmList

Detailed Description

  • Alarm manager handles one alarm request per application. This means it holds a list of each applications next alarm time stamp.
    • Applications which receive Alarm Notification Message have to send its next alarm request (if it has one).
    • If multiple applications are requesting an alarm with the same point of time the alarm manager sends the Alarm Notification Message to all applications.
    • When powering on, the Alarm Manager sends the Alarm Notification Message to all Applications which have missed an alarm during power off.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum AlarmManager::PowerOnBehavior
 

Is used to define the power-on-behavior for alarms.

Enumerator:
Default 
NoPowerOn  The default behavior set by AlarmManager::SetDefaultPowerOnBehavior.
PowerOn  The real time clock will power on the phone when the alarm expires.

Member Function Documentation

void AlarmManager::ClearAlarm (   )  [static]
 

This method has to be called, if an application wants to clear its stored ('next') alarm.

void AlarmManager::Register (   )  [static]
 

Has to be called during start-up by each execution context which wants to use the alarm manager. All these execution contexts has to overwrite the new virtual method ExecutionContext::GetGuid() by returning a GUID. The GUID is necessary to re-identify all execution contexts after each re-boot. Registration is mandatory, as in case of dynamically allocated execution context objects or future firmware update over the air AlarmManager can not identify the context (application, service thread) by its memory address (application / context pointer). The alarm manager stores the list of requested alarms if the APOXI registry and therefor application pointers can change with the next system start.

void AlarmManager::SetAlarm (  const DateTime &  alarm,
PowerOnBehavior  behavior = Default,
StartUp::Cause  startup_cause = StartUp::AlarmOn
)  [static]
 

This method has to be called by the execution context to request an alarm. When one context is calling SetAlarm multiple times, alarms with a later time stamps than the stored one are ignored. In other words: only the 'next' alarm of each execution context is handled by the alarm manager.

Parameters:
alarm Point of time for the alarm. Attention: Second information (e.g. 12:17:44) will be ignored and set to zero (->12:17:00).
behavior See AlarmManager::PowerOnBehavior.
startup_cause Defines the startup cause for the alarm, currently only StartUp::NormalOn and StartUp::AlarmOn are allowed.

void AlarmManager::SetDefaultPowerOnBehavior (  PowerOnBehavior  behavior  )  [static]
 

This method defines the power-on-behavior of all alarms, which are set to Default.
